items.title: Once He Was ‘Just Asking Questions.’ Now Tucker Carlson Is the Question.
items.summary: The conservative commentator has further fractured the right with his anti-Israel rhetoric and sympathy for a white nationalist. He’s not in the mood to apologize.

items.title: Waymo Was on a Roll in San Francisco. Then One of Its Driverless Cars Killed a Cat.
items.summary: The self-driving taxis have become ubiquitous in the city, but an uproar ensued when one ran over a beloved feline.

items.title: Maps Show How Latinos Who Shifted Right in 2024 Snapped Back Left in 2025
items.summary: The New Jersey governor’s race was the first significant sign that President Trump’s success with Hispanic voters in 2024 may have been only a temporary shift.

items.title: Mystery Fuels Unease in Maine Woods: Who Bought Burnt Jacket Mountain?
items.summary: An anonymous new owner fenced off beloved trails and put up surveillance cameras in a region with a long tradition of allowing public access on private land.

items.title: Trump Cuts Ties With Marjorie Taylor Greene, Calling Her ‘Wacky’
items.summary: The rupture exposed the divides within President Trump’s MAGA base over the Epstein files and more.

items.title: Officers were hurt in a crash while protecting Vance’s motorcade in Tennessee.
items.summary: A police officer who was on a motorcyc

items.title: Turmoil and tensions at FDA after dramatic exit of top drug regulator
items.summary: <p>Scramble to find replacement for George Tidmarsh shines light on dysfunction at US regulatory agency </p><p>After the dramatic ousting of the top drug regulator at the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) two weeks ago, officials have scrambled to find a replacement in a process that has revealed the agency’s internal cracks and tensions.</p><p>It’s troubling news for a regulatory agency that has previously enjoyed a reputation for stability and consistency.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/15/fda-us-healthcare">Continue reading...</a>

items.title: Epstein survivor pushes for release of files in wake of new emails: ‘It will bring us closure’
items.summary: <p>Marina Lacerda, 37, recounts the abuse she experienced and what inspired her to speak publicly amid new revelations</p><p>When Marina Lacerda woke on Wednesday to learn that <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/13/epstein-files-key-takeaways">thousands of documents about Jeffrey Epstein</a> had been released by House Republicans, she braced herself for a spate of new revelations.</p><p>Before deciding to waive her anonymity in September, Lacerda was known for years as “Minor Victim-1” – unknown, unheard, another teenager groomed and abused by the paedophile financier.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/15/jeffrey-epstein-survivor-marina-lacerda">Continue reading...</a>
